noun.description: Archaeology. A hollow beneath overhanging rock; a rock shelter.

origin: Mid 18th century. From French abri shelter, refuge (12th cent. in Old French; 1866 or earlier in specific archaeological use with reference to rock shelters, more fully abri sous roche, lit. shelter beneath a rock, also abri sous roches) from abrier to shelter, to protect from post-classical Latin apricare to warm, protect from cold, variant (with change of conjugation) of classical Latin aprīcārī.
